t: Proverbs 18
Through*p desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh and intermeddleth with all wisdom.
A*p fool hath no delight in understanding, but that his heart may discover itself.
When*p the wicked cometh, then cometh also contempt, and with ignominy reproach.
The*p words of a man's mouth are as deep waters, and the wellspring of wisdom as a flowing brook.
It*p is not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.
A*p fool's lips enter into contention, and his mouth calleth for strokes.
A*p fool's mouth is his destruction, and his lips are the snare of his soul.
The*p words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
He*p also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster.
The*p name of the Lord*s is a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
The*p rich man's wealth is his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.
Before*p destruction the heart of man is haughty, and before honour is humility.
He*p that answereth a matter before he heareth it, it is folly and shame unto him.
The*p spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; but a wounded spirit who can bear?
The*p heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; and the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
A*p man's gift maketh room for him, and bringeth him before great men.
He*p that is first in his own cause seemeth just; but his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.
The*p lot causeth contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty.
A*p brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city: and their contentions are like the bars of a castle.
A*p man's belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth; and with the increase of his lips shall he be filled.
Death*p and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
Whoso*p findeth a wife findeth a good thing, and obtaineth favour of the Lord.*s
The*p poor useth entreaties; but the rich answereth roughly.
A*p man that hath friends must shew himself friendly: and there is a friend that sticketh closer than a brother.
